Articles.Content:
presents

[Work in Progress]

Link to a release thread

Inline Ballutes = Parachute + Balloon

Usage: In real life ballutes are used to aerocapture ( slow down a spaceship) in upper thin atmosphere utilizing low heat and high aerodynamic surface. This is a different technique than a heat shield which has to withstand a lot of heat due to passing through much denser atmosphere. [NASA pdf document]

Due to popular interest I've decided to work on release of inline ballutes as a separate mod. For now I plan 2 or 3 sizes (3.75m, 2.5m and maybe 1.25m)

Goals: It should work more like a heat shield replacement( or addition to), not like replacement for a parachute (so all-in-one thingy). The reason behind this is that I don't want to render stock parachutes obsolete.

Preliminary stats:

1.25m ballute - 0.6t - 50m diameter - good for 15t, average for 30t etc

2.5m ballute - 1.35t - 90m diameter - good for 30t, average for 60t etc

3.75m ballute - 2.7t - 150m diameter - good for 60t, average for 100t etc

[for comparison heat shields weight atm: 1.25m = 0.3t, 2.5m = 1.3t, 3.75m = 2.8t]

- writing custom module (?)

Credits:

Enceos - texturing

Yep. Looks like the basic idea seems to be that you would send a package with a ballute, a lander, and an orbiter into the target atmosphere (the paper looks specifically at Mars, Titan, and Neptune) from a hyperbolic/flyby trajectory, deploy the ballute, let go of the orbiter early on once it was slowed enough for aerocapture, and then use the ballute to slow the lander to the point where propulsive or parachute landing would be possible. The orbiter would go into an elliptical orbit and could raise its Pe above the atmosphere with a small burn at Ap.

This seems very interesting for my RSS career. How's the FAR performance going?

I feel that same diameter value will get you worse performance under FAR. I haven't got much time to investigate this, but I feel that FAR is taking values from this lines:

preDeployedDiameter = 60
        deployedDiameter = 60

Stock is taking diameter values from those lines:

    MODULE
    {
        name = ModuleDragModifier
        dragCubeName = SEMIDEPLOYED
        dragModifier = 30
    }
    MODULE
    {
        name = ModuleDragModifier
        dragCubeName = DEPLOYED
        dragModifier = 30
    }

The problem with this is that FAR is replacing Stock module with RealChuteLite integrated into FAR and it has some static values assigned to it (max temperature, materiala etc). So I'll have to check whether there is a chance to override them.

---

All in all the question is whether we want ballutes to be :

- more 'op' so they are able to replace parachutes as well = aerobraking, aerocapture, landing or what have you

- less 'op' so they can be able to save you some dV in aerobraking phase however they are not suitable for aerocapture (not enough drag near the ground) so you still have to use them in tandem with parachutes

Did some read up on ballutes, wanted to obtain their stats compared to parachute so we can tweak values correctly and see how it fares:

stat name - ballute - parachute

material - zylon - nylon

max temp - 650 - 220 C

density - 1.54 - 1.15 g/cm3 (zylon weighs 70% more for given surface since parachute = half sphere vs sphere for ballute)

Drag = 1-5x less than conical ribbon (standard chute) for low speeds (below mach2). However can withstand much higher speeds with constant drag (unlike parachute that probably couldn't withstand higher speeds as well as couldn't behave properly - oscillation and deformation from shockwave + unbearable heat at higher speeds)

So when comparing against stock parachute, the ballute should weigh 70% more for the same drag reference area. Then its drag should vary and peak around mach 1-2 but still at low speeds it should be around 1/5 of the parachute of the same drag area. I'll continue comparing stuff next week to obtain more accurate numbers for stock balance pass.
